Award.AwardTitle: URM: Enhancing Minority Undergraduate Student Research Experiences in Ecology and Environmental Science
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Tennessee State University (TSU) to establish an Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program in order to significantly increase the number of under-represented minority students who are prepared for, and motivated to, pursue graduate studies in Ecology and Environmental Science. A cohort consisting of six students will be recruited each year in the first three years of the grant, and NSF funds will be used to support each undergraduate participant for a total of two years. Over the 4-year period of the grant, a total of eighteen students will participate in the program. The TSU URM program involves an intensive year-round research training and mentoring for undergraduates. At least six faculty members from three departments at TSU will serve as mentors and engage the students in research in a wide-range of ecological and environmental disciplines, including global change ecology, microbial ecology, environmental biology, water quality, bio/phytoremediation, and ecological modeling. Students will be paired with faculty mentors, who will provide them guidance at all stages of their laboratory research. In addition, the participants will be prepared for graduate school through activities that include GRE preparation and enhancement of communication skills, both oral and written. Students will also be encouraged to spend a summer at one of the research-intensive universities (such as NSF REU sites), to enhance their experience in research. Students are also expected to present their work at a scientific meeting. Additional information is available by contacting Dr. Dafeng Hui, the NSF URM Program Director, at dhui@tnstate.edu, or by visiting http://www.tnstate.edu/NSF-URM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) project at Tennessee State University was designed to recruit and train 18 underrepresented minority undergraduate students in research in the ecology and environmental sciences and prepare them for graduate studies.  During the funding period, we recruited and operated four cohorts of a total of 28 URM scholars. The students worked with 8 faculty mentors on undergraduate research projects in diverse areas such as global change ecology, microbial ecology, chemistry, environmental engineering, and molecular biology. Students worked with faculty mentors during the spring and fall semesters on their year-round research projects to gain hands one research experiences, collected data, and prepared posters and oral presentations at research conferences. They were provided funds to attend and present their work at conferences. In addition, these URM scholars were engaged in summer activities that included lab technical skills, career development workshops, and weekly meetings to learn other skills such as research skills, critical thinking, manuscript writing, and presentation skills that scientists need to succeed. Therefore, the project was successful in exposing URM scholars to environmental research and enhancing their ability to make a smooth transition from undergraduate to graduate studies.

Twenty five of the URM scholar have graduated with degrees in STEM majors. 14 of them either have graduated from or are currently enrolled in the graduate programs at TSU, Indiana University, Alabama A&M and other universities. All of them are underrepresented minority students.  Our URM scholars provided 24 research presentations at TSU research symposia, and Capitol symposia at the Tennessee State Capitol building, and 35 presentations at the regional and national research symposia/meetings. TSU URM scholars were authors or co-authors on over 50 research reports/abstracts including peer-reviewed articles, conference proceedings and presentations (poster and oral) at scientific meetings. Our URM program significantly enhanced minority undergraduate student research and education experiences at TSU, and effectively increased the likelihood that these students would pursue a career in biological and environmental sciences.
